newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Oversold LME aluminium perks up in Asian trade.
newsitem.headline: Oversold LME aluminium perks up in Asian trade.

text.p: London Metal Exchange (LME) three-month aluminium was trading slightly firmer on Thursday on technical factors in Asia despite a weaker tone in Tokyo aluminium futures, Far East traders said.
Three-month aluminium was trading at $1,553 a tonne at 0540 GMT, up from the late Wednesday LME close of $1,549.
"The aluminium market appears a bit oversold with the 14-day relative strength index at 32.07," an LG Futures trader said.
The market generally considers an RSI of 70 or more as overbought and 30 or less as oversold.
But TOCOM's benchmark February aluminium contract fell to 203.8 yen per kg at 0540 GMT, down 1.4 yen from Wednesday's close of 205.2 yen.
"Aluminium fell slightly on producer selling and arbitrage trading in lacklustre trading," said a trader at Japanese broker Okachi and Co Ltd.
The Okachi trader said some arbitragers were buying gold and selling aluminium on TOCOM.
LME aluminium stocks are expected to fall about 2,000 tonnes on Thursday, which should support prices, the LG trader said.

Broker Brandeis said in its daily aluminium report that the appearance of a small bearish engulfing pattern on the candlestick chart indicated a test of support around $1,535 a tonne. On the upside, it pegged resistance at $1,560.
Three-month copper is expected to range-trade between $2,240 to $2,300 a tonne due to a lack of fresh fundamental factors.
"If copper cannot breach its current psychological resistance at $2,300 a tonne, it may fall further to $2,180 a tonne," the LG trader said.
Three-month copper was firmer at $2,263 a tonne at 0530 GMT, up from late Wednesday's LME close of $2,260.
The trader LME copper stocks are also expected to fall by about 1,500 tonnes on Thursday.

Brandeis said three-month zinc prices closed technically negatively on Wednesday, wiping out all of Tuesday's gains, after briefly breaching resistance at the 10-day moving average at $1,245 a tonne. A test of $1,230 a tonne seemed likely with the next support pegged at $1,225/$1,220, it said.
